ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: No indeed! But you love this fleeting world
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: But no. You love this transient life,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: Nay; the truth is that you love ardently (the good of this world) that can be obtained hastily,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: Human beings certainly do not want to pay much attention to the Quran. In fact, they love the worldly life
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: None except you, O disbelievers – you love what you have, the fleeting one.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: But no! Rather you love the present life of this world,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: Nay! But you love the present life,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: No indeed; but you love the hasty world,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: Nay, but ye do love the fleeting Now
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: By no means! Verily ye love the Herein.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: No! Indeed, you love this transitory life
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: Nay, (ye men!) but ye love the fleeting life,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: Not [as you think, that you (mankind) will not be resurrected and recompensed for your deeds], but (you men) love the present life of this world,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: Yet you love this hasty world
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: Alas, you love the fleeting life.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: No! But you love the immediate
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [75:20] No indeed! (kallā is for commencement, with the sense of alā) Rather you love the transitory [life], this world (both verbs [here and below] may be read in the second or third person plural),
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (Nay) truly, (but ye do love the fleeting Now) working for the life of the world
